intro: Rhynchospora torreyana var. microrhyncha, commonly known as the small-rhynchospora, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Cyperaceae family, commonly referred to as the sedge family. The plant typically grows in wetland habitats, such as marshes and swamps, where it thrives in moist, nutrient-rich soils. Its inflorescence consists of a spike-like arrangement of small, greenish flowers, which are often subtended by bracts. This variety is distinguished by its compact size and reduced floral structures compared to other varieties within the species.
